metadata.paragraph_text_preview: This class action lawsuit challenges conditions at a temporary immigration detention facility known ...

target:
This class action lawsuit challenges conditions at a temporary immigration detention facility known as “Alligator Alcatraz” in the Florida Everglades. Built in June 2025, the facility consists of tents, trailers, chain-link fencing, and barbed wire, with a capacity of at least 3,000 people. It is surrounded by wetlands populated with alligators and venomous snakes. President Trump publicly stated that detainees would “learn how to run away from an alligator if they escape prison,” adding that “the only way out, really, is deportation.”

The plaintiffs are immigrants detained at “Alligator Alcatraz,” along with several organizations, including Florida Keys Immigration, the Law Offices of Catherine Perez PLLC, Sanctuary of the South, and U.S. Immigration Law Counsel. On July 16, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, they sued the Department of Homeland Security and its Secretary, the Acting Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), ICE’s Miami Field Office Director, the Governor of Florida, the Director of Miami-Dade Corrections and Rehabilitation, the Florida Division of Emergency Management and its Executive Director, and the Executive Office for Immigration Review and its Acting Director. The case was assigned to District Judge Rodolfo A. Ruiz II.

The plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification on July 17, 2025, seeking to include “all persons who are currently, or in the future, held at the Alligator Alcatraz detention facility.” That same day, they also filed an expedited motion for a temporary restraining order to ensure access to counsel and the ability to file court documents by July 21, 2025, and a preliminary injunction.

The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants restricted confidential attorney-client communication, violating detainees’ First Amendment rights to legal counsel and Fifth Amendment due process rights. They claimed the facility lacked standard protocols for private communication, such as in-person visits or unmonitored calls, leaving detainees dependent on infrequent, monitored five-minute collect calls. Attorneys reported that ICE’s detainee locator failed to show client locations, contact emails were invalid, phone calls were disconnected, and legal access was blocked at an armed checkpoint. Even when “Legal Counsel Visitation Request Forms” were provided, they often led to cancellations or no response. The plaintiffs also alleged that the government gave no guidance on which immigration courts handled bond motions, preventing detainees from contesting their detention.

On July 23, 2025, the court denied the plaintiffs’ expedited motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction as an emergency motion, ruling it was not properly certified under Local Rule 7.1(d)(1). The court treated it instead as an expedited motion and stated it would not be considered until all defendants were served and expedited briefing was ordered. Plaintiffs were directed to file a service status report by July 28, 2025. The judge also required clarification on whether the motion sought relief only for the named plaintiffs or for the entire proposed class.

On July 29, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a renewed motion for a preliminary injunction and class certification. The renewed preliminary injunction motion clarified that relief was sought for both the main class (access to counsel) and a new “bond subclass” (access to immigration courts). Unlike the original filing, it was not framed as an emergency motion. The renewed motion also included more detailed allegations, such as attorneys being stopped at a military checkpoint and visitation request forms requiring pre-approval of legal documents. The renewed motion for class certification introduced a new subclass of detainees seeking bond, added several new plaintiffs, and expanded the background with claims that the facility, which opened in early July 2025, had extreme heat, flooding, mosquitoes, and inadequate shelter.

On August 12, 2025, the court issued an order dismissing, without prejudice, defendant Sherea Green, the Director of Miami-Dade Corrections and Rehabilitation.

On August 18, 2025, the court heard the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. Later that day, the court transferred the case to the Middle District of Florida (2:25-cv-00747), where the “Alligator Alcatraz” facility is located, and dismissed the plaintiffs’ Fifth Amendment claim against the EOIR as moot after the agency identified the Krome immigration court’s jurisdiction. The court left the First Amendment access-to-counsel claims unresolved, but noted that venue for them was improper in the Southern District. The order also recorded the plaintiffs’ voluntary dismissal of one defendant and criticized the shifting nature of the plaintiffs’ filings and venue theories. The case was reassigned to Judge Sheri Chappell.

This case is ongoing.
target_paragraph: This class action lawsuit challenges conditions at a temporary immigration detention facility known as “Alligator Alcatraz” in the Florida Everglades. Built in June 2025, the facility consists of tents, trailers, chain-link fencing, and barbed wire, with a capacity of at least 3,000 people. It is surrounded by wetlands populated with alligators and venomous snakes. President Trump publicly stated that detainees would “learn how to run away from an alligator if they escape prison,” adding that “the only way out, really, is deportation.”

annotation.explanation: Plaintiffs: Class Action

A temporary detention facility called “Alligator Alcatraz” was built in June 2025 in the Florida Everglades, consisting of tents, trailers, and fencing/barbed wire, holding at least 3,000 people, surrounded by wildlife hazards; the President publicly framed escape risk in terms of alligators and deportation.

target:

It is surrounded by wetlands populated with alligators and venomous snakes. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants restricted confidential attorney-client communication, violating detainees’ First Amendment rights to legal counsel and Fifth Amendment due process rights. They claimed the facility lacked standard protocols for private communication, such as in-person visits or unmonitored calls, leaving detainees dependent on infrequent, monitored five-minute collect calls. On August 12, 2025, the court issued an order dismissing, without prejudice, defendant Sherea Green, the Director of Miami-Dade Corrections and Rehabilitation.

On August 18, 2025, the court heard the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. Later that day, the court transferred the case to the Middle District of Florida (2:25-cv-00747), where the “Alligator Alcatraz” facility is located, and dismissed the plaintiffs’ Fifth Amendment claim against the EOIR as moot after the agency identified the Krome immigration court’s jurisdiction. The court left the First Amendment access-to-counsel claims unresolved, but noted that venue for them was improper in the Southern District. The order also recorded the plaintiffs’ voluntary dismissal of one defendant and criticized the shifting nature of the plaintiffs’ filings and venue theories. The case was reassigned to Judge Sheri Chappell.

annotation.explanation: Constitutional claim under the First Amendment for access to counsel/confidential attorney-client communication; no specific statutory or case-based cause of action (e.g., 42 U.S.C. § 1983, Ex parte Young) is identified in the summary.

Constitutional claim under the Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause regarding access to immigration courts/bond and the ability to contest detention; no specific statutory or case-based cause of action is identified in the summary.
First Amendment (access-to-counsel rights)
annotation.checklist_item: Statutory or Constitutional Basis for the Case

annotation.explanation: Fifth Amendment Due Process Clause
annotation.checklist_item: Statutory or Constitutional Basis for the Case

annotation.explanation: Plaintiffs allege systemic restrictions on confidential attorney-client communication at the facility, lacking standard private communication protocols and limiting detainees to infrequent monitored five-minute collect calls, violating First Amendment and Fifth Amendment rights.

Attorneys faced practical barriers: ICE detainee locator did not display client locations, contact emails were invalid, calls were disconnected, access was blocked at an armed checkpoint, visitation request forms resulted in cancellations/no responses, and no guidance existed on which immigration court handled bond motions, impairing challenges to detention.

The order also recorded the plaintiffs’ voluntary dismissal of one defendant and criticized the shifting nature of the plaintiffs’ filings and venue theories. The case was reassigned to Judge Sheri Chappell.

This case is ongoing.

The renewed preliminary injunction motion clarified that relief was sought for both the main class (access to counsel) and a new “bond subclass” (access to immigration courts). Unlike the original filing, it was not framed as an emergency motion. The renewed motion also included more detailed allegations, such as attorneys being stopped at a military checkpoint and visitation request forms requiring pre-approval of legal documents. The renewed motion for class certification introduced a new subclass of detainees seeking bond, added several new plaintiffs, and expanded the background with claims that the facility, which opened in early July 2025, had extreme heat, flooding, mosquitoes, and inadequate shelter.

target:
This class action lawsuit challenges conditions at a temporary immigration detention facility known as “Alligator Alcatraz” in the Florida Everglades. Built in June 2025, the facility consists of tents, trailers, chain-link fencing, and barbed wire, with a capacity of at least 3,000 people. It is surrounded by wetlands populated with alligators and venomous snakes. President Trump publicly stated that detainees would “learn how to run away from an alligator if they escape prison,” adding that “the only way out, really, is deportation.”

The plaintiffs are immigrants detained at “Alligator Alcatraz,” along with several organizations, including Florida Keys Immigration, the Law Offices of Catherine Perez PLLC, Sanctuary of the South, and U.S. Immigration Law Counsel. On July 16, 2025, in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, they sued the Department of Homeland Security and its Secretary, the Acting Director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), ICE’s Miami Field Office Director, the Governor of Florida, the Director of Miami-Dade Corrections and Rehabilitation, the Florida Division of Emergency Management and its Executive Director, and the Executive Office for Immigration Review and its Acting Director. The case was assigned to District Judge Rodolfo A. Ruiz II.

The plaintiffs filed a motion for class certification on July 17, 2025, seeking to include “all persons who are currently, or in the future, held at the Alligator Alcatraz detention facility.” That same day, they also filed an expedited motion for a temporary restraining order to ensure access to counsel and the ability to file court documents by July 21, 2025, and a preliminary injunction.

The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants restricted confidential attorney-client communication, violating detainees’ First Amendment rights to legal counsel and Fifth Amendment due process rights. They claimed the facility lacked standard protocols for private communication, such as in-person visits or unmonitored calls, leaving detainees dependent on infrequent, monitored five-minute collect calls. Attorneys reported that ICE’s detainee locator failed to show client locations, contact emails were invalid, phone calls were disconnected, and legal access was blocked at an armed checkpoint. Even when “Legal Counsel Visitation Request Forms” were provided, they often led to cancellations or no response. The plaintiffs also alleged that the government gave no guidance on which immigration courts handled bond motions, preventing detainees from contesting their detention.

On July 23, 2025, the court denied the plaintiffs’ expedited motion for a temporary restraining order and preliminary injunction as an emergency motion, ruling it was not properly certified under Local Rule 7.1(d)(1). The court treated it instead as an expedited motion and stated it would not be considered until all defendants were served and expedited briefing was ordered. Plaintiffs were directed to file a service status report by July 28, 2025. The judge also required clarification on whether the motion sought relief only for the named plaintiffs or for the entire proposed class.

On July 29, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a renewed motion for a preliminary injunction and class certification. The renewed preliminary injunction motion clarified that relief was sought for both the main class (access to counsel) and a new “bond subclass” (access to immigration courts). Unlike the original filing, it was not framed as an emergency motion. The renewed motion also included more detailed allegations, such as attorneys being stopped at a military checkpoint and visitation request forms requiring pre-approval of legal documents. The renewed motion for class certification introduced a new subclass of detainees seeking bond, added several new plaintiffs, and expanded the background with claims that the facility, which opened in early July 2025, had extreme heat, flooding, mosquitoes, and inadequate shelter.

On August 12, 2025, the court issued an order dismissing, without prejudice, defendant Sherea Green, the Director of Miami-Dade Corrections and Rehabilitation.

On August 18, 2025, the court heard the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction. Later that day, the court transferred the case to the Middle District of Florida (2:25-cv-00747), where the “Alligator Alcatraz” facility is located, and dismissed the plaintiffs’ Fifth Amendment claim against the EOIR as moot after the agency identified the Krome immigration court’s jurisdiction. The court left the First Amendment access-to-counsel claims unresolved, but noted that venue for them was improper in the Southern District. The order also recorded the plaintiffs’ voluntary dismissal of one defendant and criticized the shifting nature of the plaintiffs’ filings and venue theories. The case was reassigned to Judge Sheri Chappell.

This case is ongoing.

The case was reassigned to Judge Sheri Chappell.
